main_title: The Sentiments of a Church of England Man
main_introduction: This work presents an impartial analysis of the religious and political views of a Church of England man, unbiased by any party affiliations, regardless of whether he is engaged with the Whigs or the Tories.

sections.section_introduction: This work introduces the reader to the subject matter and explains the purpose of the analysis, which is to separate myths from facts and clarify misconceptions about Church of England and its views on religion and government.

subsections.subsection_introduction: The author explains that he is qualified to analyze the sentiments of a Church of England man because he is neither a bigot in religion nor a bigot in government, converses freely with men of both parties, and his true opinion is not influenced by employment prospects or need for anonymity.
subsection_points: I have gone as far as I am able in qualifying myself to be such a moderator
I believe I am no bigot in religion
I am no bigot in government
I converse in full freedom with many considerable men of both parties
I am not under the necessity of declaring myself by the prospect of an employment
If all this be not sufficient, I industriously conceal my name
I industriously conceal my name, which wholly exempts me from any hopes and fears in delivering my opinion
subsections.subsection_conclusion: I have endeavored to be impartial and objective in my analysis of the sentiments of a Church of England man.

subsections.subsection_introduction: The author discusses the mutual misrepresentations and accusations between Whigs and Tories, and argues that no man whatsoever should be charged with principles he actually disowns, unless his practices do openly and without the least room for doubt contradict his profession.
subsection_points: It seems every man’s duty to choose a side, though he cannot entirely approve of either

To sacrifice the innocency of a friend, the good of our country, or our own conscience to the humour, or passion, or interest of a party, plainly shews that either our heads or our hearts are not as they should be
To endeavour to moderate between the rival powers, which must needs be own a fair proceeding with the world
I have gone as far as I am able in qualifying myself to be such a moderator
I believe I am no bigot in religion
I am sure I am none in government
I converse in full freedom with many considerable men of both parties
I am not under the necessity of declaring myself by the prospect of an employment
subsections.subsection_conclusion: The author aims to describe the sentiments of a Church of England man with respect to religion and government in a manner that will not be liable to least objection from either party.

sections.section_conclusion: The author is committed to navigating the complexities of religious and political beliefs in a manner that challenges and reconciles the views of both Whigs and Tories, aiming to present a clear and impartial understanding of Church of England's position.

sections.section_introduction: In this section, the author examines the sentiments of a Church of England man with regard to religion, exploring their views on topics such as Church of England's beliefs, tolerance, ecclesiastic government, and relations with other denominations.

subsections.subsection_introduction: This subsection discusses the beliefer's adherence to the principles of revealed religion and the divinity of Christ.
subsection_points: A Church of England man hath a true veneration for the scheme established among us of ecclesiastic government
A Church of England man should think the abolishment of that order among us would prove a mighty scandal and corruption to our faith
A Church of England man ought to believe a God and his providence, together with revealed religion, and the divinity of Christ
subsections.subsection_conclusion: A Church of England man upholds the established Church's beliefs in God, its providence, revealed religion, and the divinity of Christ.

subsections.subsection_introduction: This subsection addresses the Church of England's stance on tolerance in matters of religion.
subsection_points: He should therefore think the abolishment of the established order among us would prove a mighty scandal and corruption to our faith
He would defend it by arms against all the powers on earth, except our own legislature
If the clergy, or, (though this be not so fair a method) if the legislature should direct, [he would comply in altering the ceremonial or any other indifferent part of the established Church]
He cannot altogether blame the clergy for their unwillingness to consent to any alteration
He thinks it a little too gross and precipitate to employ their writers already in arguments for repealing the sacramental test
subsections.subsection_conclusion: The Church of England man advocates for tolerance in religious matters, provided that alterations to the established Church's order are made under the guidance of the clergy or the legislature and that the sacramental test remains.

subsections.subsection_introduction: This subsection emphasizes the sentiments of a Church of England man's allegiance to the established Church's ecclesiastic government and his opposition to innovations that undermine the established order.
subsection_points: A Church of England man hath a true veneration for the scheme established among us of ecclesiastic government
He thinks the abolishment of the established order among us would prove a mighty scandal and corruption to our faith
subsections.subsection_conclusion: The Church of England man upholds the established Church's ecclesiastic government and believes that its abolition would bring scandal and corruption to the faith.

subsections.subsection_introduction: This subsection sheds light on the Church of England man's stance towards other denominations within and outside of England.
subsection_points: He believes in the importance of maintaining unity among religious sects, particularly within England
He advocates for the toleration of different forms in religious worship as long as they are already admitted
He thinks it is natural for all sects to desire the abolition of the established order, which they cannot justify by any consistent principles if they do not endeavor

He holds the opinion that all rewards of trust, profit, or dignity, which the state leaves in the disposal of the administration, should be given only to those whose principles direct them to preserve the constitution in all its parts
subsections.subsection_conclusion: The Church of England man advocates for tolerance and unity in religious matters, while opposing innovations and divisions that undermine the established order within England and within the Church of England.

sections.section_conclusion: The Church of England man upholds the Church's religious beliefs, advocates for tolerance, and supports the established ecclesiastic government, while maintaining a balanced approach to relations with other denominations.

main_conclusion: By examining the sentiments of a Church of England man with respect to religion and government, this work aims to bridge the gap between the Whigs and Tories, offering a more nuanced and fair understanding of the religious and political beliefs of the Church of England.
